member.name: T:Api.Automations.CronExpression
member.summary: Provides a parser and evaluator for unix-like cron expressions always in UTC. Cron expressions provide the ability to specify complex time combinations such as "At 8:00am every Monday through Friday" or "At 1:30am every last Friday of the month".

remarks.para: Cron expressions are comprised of 6 required fields and one optional field separated by white space. The fields respectively are described as follows:
The '*' character is used to specify all values. For example, "*" in the minute field means "every minute".

The '?' character is allowed for the day-of-month and day-of-week fields. It is used to specify 'no specific value'. This is useful when you need to specify something in one of the two fields, but not the other.
The '-' character is used to specify ranges For example "10-12" in the hour field means "the hours 10, 11 and 12".
The ',' character is used to specify additional values. For example "MON,WED,FRI" in the day-of-week field means "the days Monday, Wednesday, and Friday".

The '/' character is used to specify increments. For example "0/15" in the seconds field means "the seconds 0, 15, 30, and 45". And "5/15" in the seconds field means "the seconds 5, 20, 35, and 50". Specifying '*' before the '/' is equivalent to specifying 0 is the value to start with. Essentially, for each field in the expression, there is a set of numbers that can be turned on or off. For seconds and minutes, the numbers range from 0 to 59. For hours 0 to 23, for days of the month 0 to 31, and for months 1 to 12. The "/" character simply helps you turn on every "nth" value in the given set. Thus "7/6" in the month field only turns on month "7", it does NOT mean every 6th month, please note that subtlety.

The 'L' character is allowed for the day-of-month and day-of-week fields. This character is short-hand for "last", but it has different meaning in each of the two fields. For example, the value "L" in the day-of-month field means "the last day of the month" - day 31 for January, day 28 for February on non-leap years. If used in the day-of-week field by itself, it simply means "7" or "SAT". But if used in the day-of-week field after another value, it means "the last xxx day of the month" - for example "6L" means "the last friday of the month". You can also specify an offset from the last day of the month, such as "L-3" which would mean the third-to-last day of the calendar month. When using the 'L' option, it is important not to specify lists, or ranges of values, as you'll get confusing/unexpected results.

The 'W' character is allowed for the day-of-month field. This character is used to specify the weekday (Monday-Friday) nearest the given day. As an example, if you were to specify "15W" as the value for the day-of-month field, the meaning is: "the nearest weekday to the 15th of the month". So if the 15th is a Saturday, the trigger will fire on Friday the 14th. If the 15th is a Sunday, the trigger will fire on Monday the 16th. If the 15th is a Tuesday, then it will fire on Tuesday the 15th. However if you specify "1W" as the value for day-of-month, and the 1st is a Saturday, the trigger will fire on Monday the 3rd, as it will not 'jump' over the boundary of a month's days. The 'W' character can only be specified when the day-of-month is a single day, not a range or list of days.
The 'L' and 'W' characters can also be combined for the day-of-month expression to yield 'LW', which translates to "last weekday of the month".

The '#' character is allowed for the day-of-week field. This character is used to specify "the nth" XXX day of the month. For example, the value of "6#3" in the day-of-week field means the third Friday of the month (day 6 = Friday and "#3" = the 3rd one in the month). Other examples: "2#1" = the first Monday of the month and "4#5" = the fifth Wednesday of the month. Note that if you specify "#5" and there is not 5 of the given day-of-week in the month, then no firing will occur that month. If the '#' character is used, there can only be one expression in the day-of-week field ("3#1,6#3" is not valid, since there are two expressions).
The legal characters and the names of months and days of the week are not case sensitive.

ul.li: Support for specifying both a day-of-week and a day-of-month value is not complete (you'll need to use the '?' character in one of these fields).

Overflowing ranges is supported - that is, having a larger number on the left hand side than the right. You might do 22-2 to catch 10 o'clock at night until 2 o'clock in the morning, or you might have NOV-FEB. It is very important to note that overuse of overflowing ranges creates ranges that don't make sense and no effort has been made to determine which interpretation CronExpression chooses. An example would be "0 0 14-6 ? * FRI-MON".

member.author: Sharada Jambula
James House
Contributions from Mads Henderson
Refactoring from CronTrigger to CronExpression by Aaron Craven
Marko Lahma (.NET)

member.name: M:Api.Automations.ExpressionDescriptor.GetSegmentDescription(System.String,System.String,System.Func{System.String,System.String},System.Func{System.String,System.String},System.Func{System.String,System.String},System.Func{System.String,System.String},System.Func{System.String,System.String})
member.summary:
Generates the segment description
Range expressions used the 'ComaX0ThroughX1' resource However Romanian language has different idioms for 1. 'from number to number' (minutes, seconds, hours, days) => ComaMinX0ThroughMinX1 optional resource 2. 'from month to month' ComaMonthX0ThroughMonthX1 optional resource 3. 'from year to year' => ComaYearX0ThroughYearX1 optional resource therefore was introduced
member.param: function that formats range expressions depending on cron parts

member.name: M:Api.Eventing.Events.Automation(System.String,System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Takes a cron string and returns an event handler which you can add a listener to. Generally used during startup. The event will trigger at the rate specified by your cron expression. Provide a name (typically lowercase with underscores instead of spaces) such that you can also explicitly request the automation to run from its name too. Note that if you provide a name but not the cron expression, you can add additional event handlers to an existing job.
member.param: A lowercase key for this automation. Used to trigger it and also add additional handlers to a particular event.
The 7 part cron expression from e.g. https://www.freeformatter.com/cron-expression-generator-quartz.html
Set this to true if you want all servers in a cluster to run this automation.

member.name: T:Api.Eventing.EventHandler
member.summary: Event handlers are instanced automatically and form a major part of the pluggable architecture. Modules can define events via simply extending the Events class. Handlers are also heaviest on add - they're designed to maximise repeat run performance - so avoid rapidly adding and removing them. Instead add one handler at startup and then do a check inside it to see if it should run or not.

member.name: F:Api.Eventing.EventHandler.Name
member.summary: The field name that this handler is from, if it was known.

member.name: F:Api.Eventing.EventHandler.Capability
member.summary: The capability that was created for this handler, if there is one. Only available on Before* handlers.

member.name: F:Api.Eventing.EventHandler.Attributes
member.summary: Attributes on the various event handler fields. Can be null.

member.name: F:Api.Eventing.EventHandler.PrimaryType
member.summary: The primary type of this event handler. If set, it's the type of the first arg (and also its return type). If an Api.Results.Set/ Filter type is applied here, it will be resolved into the contained type. If you want the full original type - i.e you're after Api.Results.Set/ Filter types too - use SourcePrimaryType.

member.name: F:Api.Eventing.EventHandler.SourcePrimaryType
member.summary: The primary type of this event handler. If set, it's the type of the first arg (and also its return type). Unlike primary type, this is exactly as-is in the source.

member.name: M:Api.Eventing.EventHandler.#ctor
member.summary: A place where event methods can be attached to handle events of a particular type. You often don't need to construct these - they'll be created automatically during startup. Just declare the field in the Events class.

member.name: T:Api.Permissions.Capabilities
member.summary: Capabilities are instanced automatically. You can however specify a custom type or instance them yourself if you'd like to do so.

This permissions system is roles/ capabilities based: * Users have one role. * A role is defined by a set of capabilities granted to it. * Functionality checks to see if a user has a particular capability.
Capabilities are instanced automatically. You can however specify a custom type or instance them yourself if you'd like to do so.

member.summary: A raw role grant rule. Capabilities are tested against these rules when a cap or role is added.

member.summary: The base type of this grant rule, defining the scope of the patterns. Rules are sorted by the numeric version of this.

member.name: F:Api.Permissions.RoleGrantRule.FilterQuery
member.summary: A filter query string.

member.name: F:Api.Permissions.RoleGrantRule.Patterns
member.summary: The raw pattern set inside this rule. Evaluating against these is relatively slow, however, it is only evaluated once when a capability is seen for the first time.

member.name: F:Api.Permissions.RoleGrantRule.SameAsRole
member.summary: Grant the same as this named role. Defines a base inheritence rule, which is the weakest of all rules.

member.name: M:Api.Permissions.RoleGrantRule.AsAppliedTo(Api.Permissions.Capability)
member.summary: Returns a rule as applied to the given capability. Essentially if this rule does not apply, it returns null. It can inherit from other roles, thus the actual rule returned is not necessarily this one.

member.name: T:Api.Permissions.RoleGrantRuleType
member.summary: The type of a role grant rule.

member.name: F:Api.Permissions.RoleGrantRuleType.Role
member.summary: Grant the same as the given role. Revoke is not valid with this.

member.name: F:Api.Permissions.RoleGrantRuleType.All
member.summary: All capabilities will be affected by the rule.

member.name: F:Api.Permissions.RoleGrantRuleType.Feature
member.summary: Any capability declaring a particular feature will be affected by the rule.

member.name: F:Api.Permissions.RoleGrantRuleType.Single
member.summary: A single, specific capability is affected by the rule.

member.name: F:Api.Permissions.RoleGrantRuleType.Revoke
member.summary: Revoke can be combined with any of the other options. Declares that this rule clears the current grant, if there is one. For example, revoke all is resolved before revoke single is, but after a permit all.

member.name: F:Api.Permissions.RoleGrantRuleType.Important
member.summary: Inspired by how CSS selectivity works. In this case an important rule is one which is defined by the admin panel, and overrides any of the rules that originate from code.

member.summary: Converts canvas JSON into a html-like string which will still contain component usage in there. This may be useful for sending canvas JSON to translators as it will be much more familiar for them.

member.name: M:Api.CanvasRenderer.CanvasRendererService.Render(Api.Contexts.Context,System.String,System.String,Api.CanvasRenderer.RenderMode,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Renders the named canvas. This invokes the `socialstack renderui` command if it's not already running then passes the body JSON and JSON serialized context to it.
member.param: The context that the json will be rendered as. Any data requests are made as this user.
Optional page state, JSON formatted. Is the same as pgState in JS - contains the URL, tokens and so on.
Html only, text only, both or search.
Whether to prefix URLs into an absolute path.

member.name: M:Api.CanvasRenderer.CanvasRendererService.Render(System.UInt32,System.String,System.String,System.String,Api.CanvasRenderer.RenderMode,System.Boolean)

member.param: The context that the json will be rendered as as a JSON string.
Optional page state, JSON formatted. Is the same as pgState in JS - contains the URL, tokens and so on.
Html only, text only, both or search.
Whether to prefix URLs into an absolute path.

member.summary: Reloads a prebuilt UI

member.name: M:Api.CanvasRenderer.FrontendCodeController.GetStaticFileList
member.summary: Lists all available static files.

member.name: M:Api.CanvasRenderer.FrontendCodeController.GetEmailMainJs
member.summary: Gets the email main.js file (site locale 1). The URL should be of the form /pack/email-static/main.js?loc=1&v=123123123123&h=ma83md83jd7hdur8 Where loc is the locale ID, v is the original code build timestamp in ms, and h is the hash of the file. For convenience, ask FrontendCodeService for the url via GetMainJsUrl(Context context).

member.name: M:Api.CanvasRenderer.FrontendCodeController.GetGlobalScss(System.String)
member.summary: Gets global scss (debug dev builds only) so it can be seen. Bundle is e.g. "ui" or "admin".

member.name: M:Api.CanvasRenderer.FrontendCodeController.GetMainJs
member.summary: Gets the main.js file (site locale 1). The URL should be of the form /pack/main.js?loc=1&v=123123123123&h=ma83md83jd7hdur8 Where loc is the locale ID, v is the original code build timestamp in ms, and h is the hash of the file. For convenience, ask FrontendCodeService for the url via GetMainJsUrl(Context context).

member.name: M:Api.CanvasRenderer.FrontendCodeController.GetAdminMainJs
member.summary: Gets the main.js file for the admin area (site locale 1). The URL should be of the form /en-admin/pack/main.js?loc=1&v=123123123123&h=ma83md83jd7hdur8 Where loc is the locale ID, v is the original code build timestamp in ms, and h is the hash of the file. For convenience, ask FrontendCodeService for the url via GetMainJsUrl(Context context).

member.name: M:Api.CanvasRenderer.FrontendCodeController.GetMainCss
member.summary: Gets the main.css file for the ui (site locale 1). The URL should be of the form /pack/main.css?loc=1&v=123123123123&h=ma83md83jd7hdur8 Where loc is the locale ID (currently unused), v is the original code build timestamp in ms, and h is the hash of the file. For convenience, ask FrontendCodeService for the url via GetMainJsUrl(Context context).

member.name: M:Api.CanvasRenderer.FrontendCodeController.GetAdminMainCss
member.summary: Gets the main.css file for the admin area (site locale 1). The URL should be of the form /en-admin/pack/main.css?loc=1&v=123123123123&h=ma83md83jd7hdur8 Where loc is the locale ID (currently unused), v is the original code build timestamp in ms, and h is the hash of the file. For convenience, ask FrontendCodeService for the url via GetMainJsUrl(Context context).

member.name: T:Api.CanvasRenderer.FrontendCodeService
member.summary: This service manages and generates (for devs) the frontend code. It does it by using either precompiled (as much as possible) bundles with metadata, or by compiling in-memory for devs using V8.

member.name: F:Api.CanvasRenderer.FrontendCodeService.InlineJavascriptHeader
member.summary: The inline header. This should be served inline in the html. It includes preact, preact hooks and the ss module require function, totalling 13kb.

member.summary: True if we're in prebuilt mode.

member.summary: Clears the JS caches such that the output js is reconstructed. Similar to ReloadFromFilesystem except runs on the assumption that the filesystem itself has not changed.

member.summary: Reloads a prebuilt UI from the filesystem. Use this for zero downtime UI only deployments.

member.summary: If the template literal has variables in it, this maps original variables to target ones. It's null otherwise. This exists whenever a template literal has variables in it, even if it maps a->a (non-minified source), because it verifies if the variables even exist to avoid outputting JS with syntax errors in the event that a translator typoed.

member.summary: The raw source of the template literal to use, if this is a template literal substitution segment. Look up this template literal in the list of translations. Once a match is found, check if VariableMap is set. If so, you MUST remap variables using the map before outputting.

member.name: F:Api.CanvasRenderer.JavascriptFileSegment.TemplateLiteralSource
member.summary: The raw template literal in the source. May be minified. Output this if no match was found.

member.name: F:Api.CanvasRenderer.JavascriptFileSegment.VariableMap
member.summary: If the template literal has variables in it, this maps original variables to target ones. This exists whenever a template literal has variables in it, even if it maps a->a (non-minified source), because it verifies if the variables even exist to avoid outputting JS with syntax errors in the event that a translator typoed.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the from a surrogate pair value.

The low surrogate code points maximum value.

member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this can be encoded as UTF-8 from a surrogate pair or zero otherwise.
member.param: The high surrogate code points minimum value.
The low surrogate code points maximum value.

member.name: P:Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Rune.IsValid
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this can be encoded as UTF-8
member.value: true if is valid; otherwise, false.

member.name: M:Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Rune.FullRune(System.Byte[])
member.summary: FullRune reports whether the bytes in p begin with a full UTF-8 encoding of a rune. An invalid encoding is considered a full Rune since it will convert as a width-1 error rune.
member.returns: true, if the bytes in p begin with a full UTF-8 encoding of a rune, false otherwise.

member.name: M:Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Rune.DecodeRune(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: DecodeRune unpacks the first UTF-8 encoding in p and returns the rune and its width in bytes.
member.returns: If p is empty it returns (RuneError, 0). Otherwise, if the encoding is invalid, it returns (RuneError, 1). Both are impossible results for correct, non-empty UTF-8.
member.param: Byte buffer containing the utf8 string.
Number of bytes valid in the buffer, or -1 to make it the length of the buffer.

member.name: M:Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Rune.DecodeLastRune(System.Byte[],System.Int32)
member.summary: DecodeLastRune unpacks the last UTF-8 encoding in buffer
member.returns: The last rune and its width in bytes.
member.param: Buffer to decode rune from; if it is empty, it returns (RuneError, 0). Otherwise, if the encoding is invalid, it returns (RuneError, 1). Both are impossible results for correct, non-empty UTF-8.
Scan up to that point, if the value is -1, it sets the value to the length of the buffer.
member.remarks: An encoding is invalid if it is incorrect UTF-8, encodes a rune that is out of range, or is not the shortest possible UTF-8 encoding for the value. No other validation is performed.

member.name: M:Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Rune.RuneLen(Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Rune)
member.summary: number of bytes required to encode the rune.
member.returns: The length, or -1 if the rune is not a valid value to encode in UTF-8.

member.name: M:Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Rune.EncodeRune(Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Rune,System.Byte[],System.Int32)
member.summary: Writes into the destination buffer starting at offset the UTF8 encoded version of the rune
member.returns: The number of bytes written into the destination buffer.

member.name: M:Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Rune.RuneCount(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the number of runes in a utf8 encoded buffer
member.returns: Number of runes.
member.param: Byte buffer containing a utf8 string.
Number of bytes to process in buffer, or -1 to process until the end of the buffer.

member.name: M:Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Rune.Valid(System.Byte[])
member.summary: Reports whether p consists entirely of valid UTF-8-encoded runes.
member.param: Byte buffer containing a utf8 string.

member.summary: Use to find the index of the first invalid utf8 byte sequence in a buffer
member.returns: The index of the first invalid byte sequence or -1 if the entire buffer is valid.

member.name: M:Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Rune.ValidRune(Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Rune)
member.summary: ValidRune reports whether a rune can be legally encoded as UTF-8.
member.returns: true, if rune was validated, false otherwise.

member.name: M:Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Rune.IsDigit(Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Rune)
member.summary: IsDigit reports whether the rune is a decimal digit.
member.returns: true, if the rune is a mark, false otherwise.

member.name: M:Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Rune.IsGraphic(Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Rune)
member.summary: IsGraphic reports whether the rune is defined as a Graphic by Unicode.
member.returns: true, if the rune is a lower case letter, false otherwise.
member.remarks: Such characters include letters, marks, numbers, punctuation, symbols, and spaces, from categories L, M, N, P, S, Zs.

member.name: M:Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Rune.IsPrint(Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Rune)
member.summary: IsPrint reports whether the rune is defined as printable.
member.returns: true, if the rune is a lower case letter, false otherwise.
member.remarks: Such characters include letters, marks, numbers, punctuation, symbols, and the ASCII space character, from categories L, M, N, P, S and the ASCII space character. This categorization is the same as IsGraphic except that the only spacing character is ASCII space, U+0020.

member.name: M:Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Rune.IsControl(Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Rune)
member.summary: IsControl reports whether the rune is a control character.
member.returns: true, if the rune is a lower case letter, false otherwise.
member.remarks: The C (Other) Unicode category includes more code points such as surrogates; use C.InRange (r) to test for them.

member.name: M:Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Rune.IsLetter(Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Rune)
member.summary: IsLetter reports whether the rune is a letter (category L).
member.returns: true, if the rune is a letter, false otherwise.

member.name: M:Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Rune.IsLetterOrDigit(Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Rune)
member.summary: IsLetterOrDigit reports whether the rune is a letter (category L) or a digit.
member.returns: true, if the rune is a letter or digit, false otherwise.

member.name: M:Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Rune.IsLetterOrNumber(Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Rune)
member.summary: IsLetterOrDigit reports whether the rune is a letter (category L) or a number (category N).
member.returns: true, if the rune is a letter or number, false otherwise.

member.name: M:Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Rune.IsMark(Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Rune)
member.summary: IsMark reports whether the rune is a letter (category M).
member.returns: true, if the rune is a mark, false otherwise.
member.remarks: Reports whether the rune is a mark character (category M).

member.name: M:Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Rune.IsNumber(Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Rune)
member.summary: IsNumber reports whether the rune is a letter (category N).
member.returns: true, if the rune is a mark, false otherwise.
member.remarks: Reports whether the rune is a mark character (category N).

member.summary: IsPunct reports whether the rune is a letter (category P).
member.returns: true, if the rune is a mark, false otherwise.

member.summary: IsSpace reports whether the rune is a space character as defined by Unicode's White Space property.
member.returns: true, if the rune is a mark, false otherwise.
member.remarks: In the Latin-1 space, white space includes '\t', '\n', '\v', '\f', '\r', ' ', U+0085 (NEL), U+00A0 (NBSP). Other definitions of spacing characters are set by category Z and property Pattern_White_Space.

member.name: M:Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Rune.IsSymbol(Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Rune)
member.summary: IsSymbol reports whether the rune is a symbolic character.

member.remarks:
SimpleFold iterates over Unicode code points equivalent under the Unicode-defined simple case folding. Among the code points equivalent to rune (including rune itself), SimpleFold returns the smallest rune > r if one exists, or else the smallest rune >= 0. If r is not a valid Unicode code point, SimpleFold(r) returns r.
For example:
SimpleFold('A') = 'a' SimpleFold('a') = 'A'
SimpleFold('K') = 'k' SimpleFold('k') = '\u212A' (Kelvin symbol, ) SimpleFold('\u212A') = 'K'
SimpleFold('1') = '1'
SimpleFold(-2) = -2

member.name: M:Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Rune.ColumnWidth(Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Rune)
member.summary: Number of column positions of a wide-character code. This is used to measure runes as displayed by text-based terminals.
member.returns: The width in columns, 0 if the argument is the null character, -1 if the value is not printable, otherwise the number of columns that the rune occupies.

member.name: M:Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Rune.FullRune(ustring)
member.summary: FullRune reports whether the ustring begins with a full UTF-8 encoding of a rune. An invalid encoding is considered a full Rune since it will convert as a width-1 error rune.
member.returns: true, if the bytes in p begin with a full UTF-8 encoding of a rune, false otherwise.

member.name: M:Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Rune.DecodeRune(ustring,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: DecodeRune unpacks the first UTF-8 encoding in the ustring returns the rune and its width in bytes.
member.returns: If p is empty it returns (RuneError, 0). Otherwise, if the encoding is invalid, it returns (RuneError, 1). Both are impossible results for correct, non-empty UTF-8.
member.param: Number of bytes valid in the buffer, or -1 to make it the length of the buffer.

member.name: M:Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Rune.DecodeLastRune(ustring,System.Int32)
member.summary: DecodeLastRune unpacks the last UTF-8 encoding in the ustring.
member.returns: The last rune and its width in bytes.
member.param: String to decode rune from; if it is empty, it returns (RuneError, 0). Otherwise, if the encoding is invalid, it returns (RuneError, 1). Both are impossible results for correct, non-empty UTF-8.
Scan up to that point, if the value is -1, it sets the value to the length of the buffer.
member.remarks: An encoding is invalid if it is incorrect UTF-8, encodes a rune that is out of range, or is not the shortest possible UTF-8 encoding for the value. No other validation is performed.

member.name: M:Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Rune.RuneCount(ustring)
member.summary: Returns the number of runes in a ustring.
member.returns: Number of runes.

member.name: M:Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Rune.InvalidIndex(ustring)
member.summary: Use to find the index of the first invalid utf8 byte sequence in a buffer
member.returns: The index of the first invalid byte sequence or -1 if the entire buffer is valid.

member.name: M:Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Rune.Valid(ustring)
member.summary: Reports whether the ustring consists entirely of valid UTF-8-encoded runes.

member.name: M:Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Rune.ExpectedSizeFromFirstByte(System.Byte)
member.summary: Given one byte from a utf8 string, return the number of expected bytes that make up the sequence.
member.returns: The number of UTF8 bytes expected given the first prefix.
member.param: Is the first byte of a UTF8 sequence.

member.name: T:Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Unicode
member.summary: Unicode class contains helper methods to support Unicode encoding.

remarks.para: Generally the Unicode class provided methods that can help you classify and convert Unicode code points. The word codepoint is considered a mouthful so in this class, the word "rune" is used instead and is represented by the uint value type.

Unicode code points can be produced by combining independent characters, so the rune for a character can be produced by combining one character and other elements of it. Runes on the other hand correspond to a specific character.

This class surfaces various methods to classify case of a Rune, like , , , to convert runes from one case to another using the , , as well as various constants that are useful when working with Unicode runes.
Unicode defines various character classes which are surfaced as RangeTables as static properties in this class. You can probe whether a rune belongs to a specific range table

member.name: F:Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Unicode.Version
member.summary: Version is the Unicode edition from which the tables are derived.

member.summary: IsDigit reports whether the rune is a decimal digit.
member.returns: true, if the rune is a mark, false otherwise.

member.name: F:Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Unicode.GraphicRanges
member.summary: The range tables for graphics

member.name: F:Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Unicode.PrintRanges
member.summary: The range tables for print

member.name: M:Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Unicode.IsRuneInRanges(System.UInt32,Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Unicode.RangeTable[])
member.summary: Determines if a rune is on a set of ranges.
member.returns: true, if rune in ranges was used, false otherwise.

member.name: M:Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Unicode.IsGraphic(System.UInt32)
member.summary: IsGraphic reports whether the rune is defined as a Graphic by Unicode.
member.returns: true, if the rune is a lower case letter, false otherwise.
member.remarks: Such characters include letters, marks, numbers, punctuation, symbols, and spaces, from categories L, M, N, P, S, Zs.

member.name: M:Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Unicode.IsPrint(System.UInt32)
member.summary: IsPrint reports whether the rune is defined as printable.
member.returns: true, if the rune is a lower case letter, false otherwise.
member.remarks: Such characters include letters, marks, numbers, punctuation, symbols, and the ASCII space character, from categories L, M, N, P, S and the ASCII space character. This categorization is the same as IsGraphic except that the only spacing character is ASCII space, U+0020.

member.name: M:Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Unicode.IsControl(System.UInt32)
member.summary: IsControl reports whether the rune is a control character.
member.returns: true, if the rune is a lower case letter, false otherwise.
member.remarks: The C (Other) Unicode category includes more code points such as surrogates; use C.InRange (r) to test for them.

member.name: M:Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Unicode.IsLetter(System.UInt32)
member.summary: IsLetter reports whether the rune is a letter (category L).
member.returns: true, if the rune is a letter, false otherwise.

member.name: M:Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Unicode.IsMark(System.UInt32)
member.summary: IsMark reports whether the rune is a letter (category M).
member.returns: true, if the rune is a mark, false otherwise.
member.remarks: Reports whether the rune is a mark character (category M).

member.name: M:Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Unicode.IsNumber(System.UInt32)
member.summary: IsNumber reports whether the rune is a letter (category N).
member.returns: true, if the rune is a mark, false otherwise.
member.remarks: Reports whether the rune is a mark character (category N).

member.name: M:Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Unicode.IsPunct(System.UInt32)
member.summary: IsPunct reports whether the rune is a letter (category P).
member.returns: true, if the rune is a mark, false otherwise.
member.remarks: Reports whether the rune is a mark character (category P).

member.name: M:Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Unicode.IsSpace(System.UInt32)
member.summary: IsSpace reports whether the rune is a space character as defined by Unicode's White Space property.
member.returns: true, if the rune is a mark, false otherwise.
member.remarks: In the Latin-1 space, white space includes '\t', '\n', '\v', '\f', '\r', ' ', U+0085 (NEL), U+00A0 (NBSP). Other definitions of spacing characters are set by category Z and property Pattern_White_Space.

member.name: M:Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Unicode.IsSymbol(System.UInt32)
member.summary: IsSymbol reports whether the rune is a symbolic character.
member.returns: true, if the rune is a mark, false otherwise.

member.name: M:Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Unicode.RangeTable.IsExcludingLatin(System.UInt32)

member.returns: true, if the rune is part of the range (not including latin), false otherwise.

member.summary: To maps the rune to the specified case: Case.Upper, Case.Lower, or Case.Title

member.summary: ToLower maps the rune to lower case giving priority to the special mapping.
member.returns: The lower cased rune if it can be.

member.name: M:Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Unicode.SimpleFold(System.UInt32)
member.summary: SimpleFold iterates over Unicode code points equivalent under the Unicode-defined simple case folding.
member.returns: The simple-case folded rune.
member.remarks:
SimpleFold iterates over Unicode code points equivalent under the Unicode-defined simple case folding. Among the code points equivalent to rune (including rune itself), SimpleFold returns the smallest rune > r if one exists, or else the smallest rune >= 0. If r is not a valid Unicode code point, SimpleFold(r) returns r.
For example:
SimpleFold('A') = 'a' SimpleFold('a') = 'A'
SimpleFold('K') = 'k' SimpleFold('k') = '\u212A' (Kelvin symbol, ) SimpleFold('\u212A') = 'K'
SimpleFold('1') = '1'
SimpleFold(-2) = -2

member.name: T:Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Utf8
member.summary: UTF8 Helper methods and routines.
member.remarks: The term "rune" is used to represent a Unicode code point merely because it is a shorter way of talking about it.

member.name: F:Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Utf8.RuneError
member.summary: The "error" Rune or "Unicode replacement character"

member.name: F:Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Utf8.RuneSelf
member.summary: Characters below RuneSelf are represented as themselves in a single byte

member.name: F:Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Utf8.Utf8Max
member.summary: Maximum number of bytes required to encode every unicode code point.

member.name: F:Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Utf8.MaxRune
member.summary: Maximum valid Unicode code point.

member.name: M:Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Utf8.FullRune(System.Byte[])
member.summary: FullRune reports whether the bytes in p begin with a full UTF-8 encoding of a rune. An invalid encoding is considered a full Rune since it will convert as a width-1 error rune.
member.returns: true, if the bytes in p begin with a full UTF-8 encoding of a rune, false otherwise.

member.name: M:Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Utf8.FullRune(ustring)
member.summary: FullRune reports whether the ustring begins with a full UTF-8 encoding of a rune. An invalid encoding is considered a full Rune since it will convert as a width-1 error rune.
member.returns: true, if the bytes in p begin with a full UTF-8 encoding of a rune, false otherwise.

member.name: M:Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Utf8.DecodeRune(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: DecodeRune unpacks the first UTF-8 encoding in p and returns the rune and its width in bytes.
member.returns: If p is empty it returns (RuneError, 0). Otherwise, if the encoding is invalid, it returns (RuneError, 1). Both are impossible results for correct, non-empty UTF-8.
member.param: Byte buffer containing the utf8 string.
Number of bytes valid in the buffer, or -1 to make it the lenght of the buffer.

member.name: M:Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Utf8.DecodeRune(ustring,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: DecodeRune unpacks the first UTF-8 encoding in the ustring returns the rune and its width in bytes.
member.returns: If p is empty it returns (RuneError, 0). Otherwise, if the encoding is invalid, it returns (RuneError, 1). Both are impossible results for correct, non-empty UTF-8.
member.param: Number of bytes valid in the buffer, or -1 to make it the lenght of the buffer.

member.name: M:Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Utf8.DecodeLastRune(System.Byte[],System.Int32)
member.summary: DecodeLastRune unpacks the last UTF-8 encoding in buffer
member.returns: The last rune and its width in bytes.
member.param: Buffer to decode rune from; if it is empty, it returns (RuneError, 0). Otherwise, if the encoding is invalid, it returns (RuneError, 1). Both are impossible results for correct, non-empty UTF-8.
Scan up to that point, if the value is -1, it sets the value to the lenght of the buffer.
member.remarks: An encoding is invalid if it is incorrect UTF-8, encodes a rune that is out of range, or is not the shortest possible UTF-8 encoding for the value. No other validation is performed.

member.name: M:Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Utf8.DecodeLastRune(ustring,System.Int32)
member.summary: DecodeLastRune unpacks the last UTF-8 encoding in the ustring.
member.returns: The last rune and its width in bytes.
member.param: String to decode rune from; if it is empty, it returns (RuneError, 0). Otherwise, if the encoding is invalid, it returns (RuneError, 1). Both are impossible results for correct, non-empty UTF-8.
Scan up to that point, if the value is -1, it sets the value to the lenght of the buffer.
member.remarks: An encoding is invalid if it is incorrect UTF-8, encodes a rune that is out of range, or is not the shortest possible UTF-8 encoding for the value. No other validation is performed.

member.name: M:Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Utf8.RuneLen(System.UInt32)
member.summary: number of bytes required to encode the rune.
member.returns: The length, or -1 if the rune is not a valid value to encode in UTF-8.

member.name: M:Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Utf8.EncodeRune(System.UInt32,System.Byte[],System.Int32)
member.summary: Writes into the destination buffer starting at offset the UTF8 encoded version of the rune
member.returns: The number of bytes written into the destination buffer.

member.name: M:Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Utf8.RuneCount(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the number of runes in a utf8 encoded buffer
member.returns: Numnber of runes.
member.param: Byte buffer containing a utf8 string.
Number of bytes to process in buffer, or -1 to process until the end of the buffer.

member.name: M:Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Utf8.RuneCount(ustring)
member.summary: Returns the number of runes in a ustring.
member.returns: Numnber of runes.

member.name: M:Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Utf8.Valid(System.Byte[])
member.summary: Reports whether p consists entirely of valid UTF-8-encoded runes.
member.param: Byte buffer containing a utf8 string.

member.name: M:Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Utf8.Valid(ustring)
member.summary: Reports whether the ustring consists entirely of valid UTF-8-encoded runes.

member.name: M:Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Utf8.InvalidIndex(System.Byte[])
member.summary: Use to find the index of the first invalid utf8 byte sequence in a buffer
member.returns: The index of the first insvalid byte sequence or -1 if the entire buffer is valid.

member.name: M:Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Utf8.InvalidIndex(ustring)
member.summary: Use to find the index of the first invalid utf8 byte sequence in a buffer
member.returns: The index of the first insvalid byte sequence or -1 if the entire buffer is valid.

member.name: M:Api.Startup.Utf8Helpers.Utf8.ValidRune(System.UInt32)
member.summary: ValidRune reports whether a rune can be legally encoded as UTF-8.
member.returns: true, if rune was valided, false otherwise.

member.name: T:Api.Startup.CacheConfig`1
member.summary: Config indicating how a service should cache its content.

member.name: F:Api.Startup.CacheConfig`1.OnChange
member.summary: Runs when an item has been updated. If the first object is null and the second is not null, this is a first time add. If they're both set, it's an update. If the first is not null and the second is set, it's a removal of some kind. Note that you may wish to check if the object change is for a particular locale (via the given context object). An object with the same ID can pass through repeatedly, but with different translations.

member.name: T:Api.Startup.CacheConfig

member.name: T:Api.Startup.EventListenerAttribute
member.summary: Use this in your module to be able to hook up to early events such as the ones that happen during service configure. These are always instanced during startup. Note that services themselves are also instanced during startup so you can also hook up events from their constructors (just not the particularly early events). Note that Services.Get is unavailable during the constructor - you'll need to use the Services.OnStart event to grab services.

member.name: F:Api.Startup.ServiceEventGroup.AfterStart
member.summary: Called just after all services have started for the first time, exactly once. Note that services may start at random points in the future, and this handler won't be invoked then - don't use this event to e.g. loop over available services. Instead, handle the Create and Delete events.

member.name: T:Api.Startup.Pluralise
member.summary: Helper class for handling basic plurals of words (usually content types). Not intended to be completely accurate; just fast and accurate for the vast majority of words it will encounter.

member.name: F:Api.Startup.Pluralise.exceptions
member.summary: Exception list.

member.name: M:Api.Startup.Pluralise.FirstLetterToUpper(System.String)
member.summary: Uppercases first letter of word.

member.name: M:Api.Startup.Pluralise.NiceName(System.String)
member.summary: Adds spaces into the given text. E.g. "BlogPost" becomes "Blog Post".

member.name: M:Api.Startup.Pluralise.Apply(System.String)
member.summary: Attempts to pluralize the specified text according to the rules of the English language.
member.remarks:
This function attempts to pluralize as many words as practical by following these rules:
Words that don't follow any rules (e.g. "mouse" becomes "mice") are returned from a dictionary.
Words that end with "y" (but not with a vowel preceding the y) are pluralized by replacing the "y" with "ies".
Words that end with "us", "ss", "x", "ch" or "sh" are pluralized by adding "es" to the end of the text.
Words that end with "f" or "fe" are pluralized by replacing the "f(e)" with "ves".
member.returns: A string that consists of the given singular word in its pluralized form, in lowercase.

member.name: T:Api.Startup.VirtualFieldValueGenerator`2
member.summary: Inherit this to define a virtual field value generator. Value generators let you define custom code for an includable name. primaryUrl is an example of a value generator (it's in the Pages module). The name of the includable field simply originates from the name of the class; it's your class name, minus ValueGenerator (if it ends with it), then camelCase'd. A usage template is available at the bottom of this file.

member.name: T:Api.Uploader.WebpConfig
member.summary: Webp config.

member.name: P:Api.Uploader.WebpConfig.Quality
member.summary: Gets or sets the compression value for image quality between 0 and 100

member.name: P:Api.Uploader.WebpConfig.AlphaCompression
member.summary: Gets or sets the encoding of the alpha plane (webp:alpha-compression).

member.name: P:Api.Uploader.WebpConfig.AlphaFiltering
member.summary: Gets or sets the predictive filtering method for the alpha plane (webp:alpha-filtering).

member.name: P:Api.Uploader.WebpConfig.AlphaQuality
member.summary: Gets or sets the compression value for alpha compression between 0 and 100. Lossless compression of alpha is achieved using a value of 100, while the lower values result in a lossy compression (webp:alpha-quality).

member.name: P:Api.Uploader.WebpConfig.AutoFilter
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating wether the algorithm should spend additional time optimizing the filtering strength to reach a well-balanced quality (webp:auto-filter).

member.name: P:Api.Uploader.WebpConfig.EmulateJpegSize
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating wether a similar compression to that of JPEG but with less degradation should be used. (webp:emulate-jpeg-size).

member.name: P:Api.Uploader.WebpConfig.Exact
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating wether RGB values should be preserved in transparent area. It's disabled by default to help compressibility.

member.name: P:Api.Uploader.WebpConfig.FilterSharpness
member.summary: Gets or sets strength of the filter sharpness, between 0 and 7 (least sharp) (webp:filter-sharpness).

member.name: P:Api.Uploader.WebpConfig.FilterStrength
member.summary: Gets or sets strength of the deblocking filter, between 0 (no filtering) and 100 (maximum filtering). A value of 0 turns off any filtering. Higher values increase the strength of the filtering process applied after decoding the image. The higher the value, the smoother the image appears. Typical values are usually in the range of 20 to 50 (webp:filter-strength).

member.name: P:Api.Uploader.WebpConfig.FilterType
member.summary: Gets or sets the filter type. (webp:filter-type).

member.name: P:Api.Uploader.WebpConfig.ImageHint
member.summary: Gets or sets the hint about the image type. (webp:image-hint).

member.name: P:Api.Uploader.WebpConfig.Lossless
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating wether the image should be encoded without any loss (webp:lossless).

member.name: P:Api.Uploader.WebpConfig.LowMemory
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating wether the memory usage should be reduced (webp:low-memory).

member.name: P:Api.Uploader.WebpConfig.Method
member.summary: Gets or sets the compression method to use. It controls the trade off between encoding speed and the compressed file size and quality. Possible values range from 0 to 6. Default value is 4. When higher values are utilized, the encoder spends more time inspecting additional encoding possibilities and decide on the quality gain. Lower value might result in faster processing time at the expense of larger file size and lower compression quality (webp:method).

member.name: P:Api.Uploader.WebpConfig.NearLossless
member.summary: Gets or sets the near lossless encoding, between 0 (max-loss) and 100 (off) (webp:near-lossless).

member.name: P:Api.Uploader.WebpConfig.PartitionLimit
member.summary: Gets or sets the partition limit. Choose 0 for no quality degradation and 100 for maximum degradation (webp:partition-limit).

member.name: P:Api.Uploader.WebpConfig.Partitions
member.summary: Gets or sets progressive decoding: choose 0 to 3 (webp:partitions).

member.name: P:Api.Uploader.WebpConfig.Pass
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum number of passes to target compression size or PSNR (webp:pass).

member.name: P:Api.Uploader.WebpConfig.Preprocessing
member.summary: Gets or sets the preprocessing filter (webp:preprocessing).

member.name: P:Api.Uploader.WebpConfig.Segment
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum number of segments to use, choose from 1 to 4 (webp:segment).

member.name: P:Api.Uploader.WebpConfig.ShowCompressed
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating wether the compressed picture should be exported back (webp:show-compressed).

member.name: P:Api.Uploader.WebpConfig.SnsStrength
member.summary: Gets or sets he amplitude of the spatial noise shaping. Spatial noise shaping (SNS) refers to a general collection of built-in algorithms used to decide which area of the picture should use relatively less bits, and where else to better transfer these bits. The possible range goes from 0 (algorithm is off) to 100 (the maximal effect). The default value is 80 (webp:sns-strength).

member.name: P:Api.Uploader.WebpConfig.TargetPsnr
member.summary: Gets or sets the desired minimal distortion (webp:target-psnr).

member.name: P:Api.Uploader.WebpConfig.TargetSize
member.summary: Gets or sets the target size (in bytes) to try and reach for the compressed output. The compressor makes several passes of partial encoding in order to get as close as possible to this target. (webp:target-size).

member.name: P:Api.Uploader.WebpConfig.ThreadLevel
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating wether multi-threaded encoding should be enabled (webp:thread-level).

member.name: P:Api.Uploader.WebpConfig.UseSharpYuv
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating wether sharp (and slow) RGB->YUV conversion should be used. (webp:use-sharp-yuv).

member.name: M:Api.Uploader.UploadController.FileConsistency(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Performs a file consistency check, where it will make sure each identified ref file matches the current upload policy. In the future this will also add any missing database entries.
member.param: An ISO date string in UTC. Regenerate files if they are before the specified date.

Of the form "1-500" inclusive. Will skip any files with an upload ID out of this range if specified. Can be used for bulk task delegation amongst a group of machines. Use blank values for "anything after" ("100-") and "anything before" ("-100").

member.name: T:Api.Uploader.UploaderConfig
member.summary: Configuration settings relating to file uploads and image processing.

member.name: P:Api.Uploader.UploaderConfig.ImageSizes
member.summary: When an image is uploaded, it'll be automatically resized to each of these sizes.

member.name: P:Api.Uploader.UploaderConfig.ImageCrops
member.summary: When an image is uploaded, it'll be automatically resized to the exact height and width defined in this list. This isn't necessarily the same aspect ratio as the original image, so cropping can occur. It is recommended to set a focal point prior to resizing, as this will be used to inform how the cropped image is produced. Note that sizes are defined in [height]x[width] format (e.g. "177x118"), with an optional zoom level (e.g. "1024x768@3x")

member.name: P:Api.Uploader.UploaderConfig.ProcessImages
member.summary: True if image uploads should be processed.

member.name: P:Api.Uploader.UploaderConfig.TranscodeToWebP
member.summary: True if all image uploads should be transcoded to webp, unless they were webp already. If it's already a web friendly format like png or jpg, the original will be resized as well.

member.name: F:Api.Uploader.UploadService._resizeGroups
member.summary: To make image resizing as efficient as possible without repeatedly reloading the source into memory a set of "resize groups" are made. These are based on the sizes in the configuration and are sorted into multiples. For example, powers of 2 are grouped together. Using default config, 2 groups exist: 2048, 1024, 512, .. 32 is one, and 200, 100 is the other.

member.summary: The directive of the context itself.

member.summary: The list of contexts within this context. NGINX context (blocks) are nestable.

member.summary: The classic key/value pairing which defines a particular config value is called a directive. It is a list rather than a dictionary because for a variety of directives, order matters.

member.summary: Add a context of the given type as a child. Returns the new context. See also: AddLocationContext. Returns *the child context*.

member.name: M:Api.CloudHosts.NGINXContext.AddContext(Api.CloudHosts.NGINXContext)
member.summary: Adds the given context to this one as a child context. Returns *the child context*.

member.name: M:Api.CloudHosts.NGINXContext.AddDirective(System.String,System.String)
member.summary:
Adds the given directive (key/value config pair) to this one as a child. Returns this context for easy chaining. Like this:
nginxConfigFile.AddDirective("error_log", "/var/log/nginx/error.log").AddDirective("server_name", "www.site.com")...
If you need the actual NGINXDirective object, use the other AddDirective.

member.name: M:Api.CloudHosts.NGINXContext.AddDirective(Api.CloudHosts.NGINXDirective)
member.summary: Adds the given directive (key/value config pair) to this one as a child.

member.summary: Generates the textual configuration of this context.

member.summary: Efficient mechanism for stringifying this block.

member.name: M:Api.CloudHosts.NGINXContext.Indent(System.Text.StringBuilder,System.Int32)
member.summary: Adds tabs to the given builder based on the current indent depth. I.e. depth 0 is 0 tabs added, 1 is 1 tab added etc.

member.name: T:Api.CloudHosts.NGINXDirective
member.summary:
A class which represents a "directive" in NGINX config lingo. Essentially a key/value pair which sets a particular piece of config. Some directives are order sensitive so they are a list not a dictionary.
error_log "/var/log/nginx/error.log"; -- a directive ^ ^ key value

member.summary: Creates a new NGINX directive with the given key/ value pair.

member.summary: Efficient mechanism for stringifying this directive. Does not output ; as the presence of the semicolon varies based on where the directive is.

member.name: T:Api.Configuration.Config
member.summary: Base class of every configuration block. To create config for your service, create a class that inherits this called {ServiceName}Config. For example, if your config is for ThingService, then you would * Make public partial class ThingServiceConfig : Config * GetConfig<ThingServiceConfig>() in e.g. the constructor of ThingService. Use the BeforeConfigure event to track when it's about to change. Config is JSON serialised so it can contain lists and sub classes as well.

member.name: M:Api.Contexts.ContextService.CreateRemoteToken(Api.Contexts.Context,System.String,Api.Signatures.KeyPair)
member.summary: Creates a token for accessing a remote site which permits access to the given hostname. The given keypair must contain the private key that we'll use, and the remote system must have the public key in its SignatureService Hosts config.
member.param: The context to create the token for.

If provided, a hostname to use in the token. You can define a lookup of remote public keys in your SignatureService config, allowing third party systems to create valid tokens. This hostname is the key in that lookup.
A keypair just for the purpose of accessing the remote host. It must not be the same as the main keypair for this site.

By default, unless you specify [CacheOnly] on your type, the entity will be stored in the database. A database table will always have the columns defined here as fields. Will often be ContentType{int}

member.name: T:Api.Users.VersionedContent`1
member.summary: Use this to get a UserId, CreatedUtc and EditedUtc with automatic creator user field support, which is also capable of revisions. Alternatively use DatabaseRow directly if you want total control over your table.

Use this to get a UserId, CreatedUtc and EditedUtc with automatic creator user field support, which is also capable of revisions. Alternatively use DatabaseRow directly if you want total control over your table.

member.name: F:Api.Users.VersionedContent`1.Revision
member.summary: The revision number of a particular piece of content. Starts at 1 and goes up linearly.

member.name: F:Api.Users.VersionedContent`1._RevisionId
member.summary: This is only set if you have a revision object of the content. This is always null for the latest content. This is unique within all revisions for a particular type. It's the row ID for the revisions table, and doesn't exist at all in the main type table.

member.name: P:Api.Users.VersionedContent`1.RevisionId
member.summary: This is only set if you have a revision object of the content. This is always null for the latest content (what you'll have most of the time).

member.name: F:Api.Users.VersionedContent`1._IsDraft
member.summary: This is true if this revision is a draft. It's false if you don't have a revision object.

member.name: P:Api.Users.VersionedContent`1.IsDraft
member.summary: This is true if this revision is a draft. It's false if you don't have a revision object.

member.name: M:Api.ErrorLogging.LogTransactionReader.StartReadForwards(System.UInt64,System.Int32)
member.summary: Sets up this reader for forward reading.
member.param: The size of the read buffer. Usually you don't need to change this.

The total size, in bytes, of other parts of the blockchain before the one that is being read from here. If the blockchain is in one file, this value is 0. If you have partial files, you can obtain it via the "Byte Offset" field in the nearest block boundary transaction.

member.summary: Called when a transaction is in the buffer

member.name: M:Api.ErrorLogging.LogTransactionReader.StartReadBackwards(System.IO.Stream,System.UInt64,System.Int32)
member.summary: Loads the transactions from the open read stream in the backwards direction. This is useful for state loading, as you can e.g. skip setting values which are overriden by future transactions.

member.name: M:Api.Pages.PageService.InstallAdminPages(System.Type,System.String[],Api.Startup.ChildAdminPageOptions)
member.summary: Installs generic admin pages using the given fields to display on the list page.
member.param: The content type that is being installed (Page, Blog etc)

A shortcut for specifying that your type has some kind of sub-type. For example, the NavMenu admin page specifies a child type of NavMenuItem, meaning each NavMenu ends up with a list of NavMenuItems. Make sure you specify the fields that'll be visible from the child type in the list on the parent type. For example, if you'd like each child entry to show its Id and Title fields, specify new string[]{"id", "title"}.

member.summary:
A virtual field value generator for a field called "primaryUrl". You can include this field on any type and it will provide the URL of the page where the object is the primary content. See also: Primary Content on the wiki.
Automatically instanced and the include field name is derived from the class name by the includes system. See VirtualFieldValueGenerator for more info.

member.summary: The # of url pieces after the primary content type is referenced. In the url /news/{blogpost.slug}/edit, {blogpost.slug} is the primary content type reference. It has one piece after it. /news/{blogpost.slug}/edit/permissions has 2 pieces after it and is therefore more specific and not the main page for the content type.

member.summary: AES 2nd tier perfomance vs. memory. Originally from BouncyCastle and upgraded to support stackalloc spans.

member.name: T:AutoService`2
member.summary: A general use service which manipulates an entity type. In the global namespace due to its common use. Deletes, creates, lists and updates them whilst also firing off a series of events. Note that you don't have to inherit this to create a service - it's just for convenience for common functionality. Services are actually detected purely by name.

member.name: T:AutoService
member.summary: The base class of all AutoService instances.

A general use service which manipulates an entity type. In the global namespace due to its common use. Deletes, creates, lists and updates them whilst also firing off a series of events. Note that you don't have to inherit this to create a service - it's just for convenience for common functionality. Services are actually detected purely by name.
The base class of all AutoService instances.
The base class of all AutoService instances.

member.summary: Get config. Always returns the latest configuration. You can safely reuse references to the object returned - if the config changes, it'll still be the same object. You can find when it changes (or loads the first time) via the Config.OnChange event. Also note that the config section key is the name of the given type, minus "Config" or "Configuration" from the end. Optionally stores a default config entry in the database if none were found.

member.name: M:AutoService.InstallAdminPages(System.String,System.String,System.String[],Api.Startup.ChildAdminPageOptions,System.String)
member.summary: Installs generic admin pages for this service, including the nav menu entry. Does nothing if there isn't a page service installed, or if the admin pages already exist.
member.param: The text to show on the navmenu.
The ref for the icon to use on the navmenu. Usually a fontawesome icon, of the form "fa:fa-thing".
The fields to show in the list of your content type. Usually include at least some sort of name or title.

A shortcut for specifying that your type has some kind of sub-type. For example, the NavMenu admin page specifies a child type of NavMenuItem, meaning each NavMenu ends up with a list of NavMenuItems. Make sure you specify the fields that'll be visible from the child type in the list on the parent type. For example, if you'd like each child entry to show its Id and Title fields, specify new string[]{"id", "title"}.

member.name: M:System.Log.Error(System.String,System.Exception,System.String)
member.summary: Logs an error message for the given tag. It is strongly recommended to pass the exception here too such that the stack trace will be logged. The tag SHOULD be lowercase separated with hypens or underscores and represents a subset of logs. It is suggested to use Service.LogTag: the lowercase type name, or the lowercase service name if you don't have a type.

member.name: M:System.Log.Fatal(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Logs a fatal error message for the given tag. It is strongly recommended to pass the exception here too such that the stack trace will be logged. Fatal exceptions usually happen just before or during a total application failure. For this reason, they are very high priority. That means logging a fatal error will force all buffers to flush. If the link to the log store is down then they will be flushed to a file for safe keeping until service is restored. The tag SHOULD be lowercase separated with hypens or underscores and represents a subset of logs. It is suggested to use Service.LogTag: the lowercase type name, or the lowercase service name if you don't have a type.

If the link to the log store is down then they will be flushed to a file for safe keeping until service is restored. The tag SHOULD be lowercase separated with hypens or underscores and represents a subset of logs. member.name: T:CryptSharp.Crypter
member.summary: Crypts and verifies passwords. The main class for most uses of this library.

member.summary: Checks if the particular crypt algorithm is compatible with the salt string or crypted password.

member.returns: true if the algorithm is compatible.

member.name: M:CryptSharp.Crypter.Crypt(System.String)
member.summary: Creates a one-way password hash (crypted password) from a password string.
member.param: The password string. Characters are UTF-8 encoded.
member.returns: The crypted password.

member.name: M:CryptSharp.Crypter.Crypt(System.String,CryptSharp.CrypterOptions)
member.summary: Creates a one-way password hash (crypted password) from a password string. Options modify the crypt operation.
member.param: The password string. Characters are UTF-8 encoded.
member.returns: The crypted password.

member.name: M:CryptSharp.Crypter.Crypt(System.String,System.String)
member.summary:
Creates a one-way password hash (crypted password) from a password string and a salt string.
The salt can be produced using . Because crypted passwords take the form algorithm+salt+hash, if you pass a crypted password as the salt parameter, the same algorithm and salt will be used to re-crypt the password. Since randomness comes from the salt, the same salt means the same hash, and so the same crypted password will result. Therefore, this method can both generate *and* verify crypted passwords.
member.param: The password string. Characters are UTF-8 encoded.
The salt string or crypted password containing a salt string.
member.returns: The crypted password.

member.name: M:CryptSharp.Crypter.Crypt(System.Byte[])
member.summary: Creates a one-way password hash (crypted password) from password bytes.
member.returns: The crypted password.

member.name: M:CryptSharp.Crypter.Crypt(System.Byte[],CryptSharp.CrypterOptions)
member.summary: Creates a one-way password hash (crypted password) from password bytes. Options modify the crypt operation.
member.returns: The crypted password.

member.name: M:CryptSharp.Crypter.Crypt(System.Byte[],System.String)
member.summary:
Creates a one-way password hash (crypted password) from password bytes and a salt string.
The salt can be produced using . Because crypted passwords take the form algorithm+salt+hash, if you pass a crypted password as the salt parameter, the same algorithm and salt will be used to re-crypt the password. Since randomness comes from the salt, the same salt means the same hash, and so the same crypted password will result. Therefore, this method can both generate *and* verify crypted passwords.
member.param: The salt string or crypted password containing a salt string.
member.returns: The crypted password.

member.name: M:CryptSharp.Crypter.GenerateSalt
member.summary: Generates a salt string with default options. The purpose of salt is to make dictionary attacks against a whole password database much harder, by causing the crypted password to be different even if two users have the same uncrypted password.
member.returns: The salt string.

member.name: M:CryptSharp.Crypter.GenerateSalt(System.Int32)
member.summary: Generates a salt string using the specified number of rounds. The purpose of salt is to make dictionary attacks against a whole password database much harder, by causing the crypted password to be different even if two users have the same uncrypted password.
member.returns: The salt string.

member.name: M:CryptSharp.Crypter.GenerateSalt(CryptSharp.CrypterOptions)
member.summary:
Generates a salt string. Options are used to modify the salt generation. The purpose of salt is to make dictionary attacks against a whole password database much harder, by causing the crypted password to be different even if two users have the same uncrypted password.
Randomness in a crypted password comes from its salt string, as do all recorded options. The same salt string, when combined with the same password, will generate the same crypted password. If the salt string differs, the same password will generate a different crypted password (crypted passwords have the form algorithm+salt+hash, so the salt is always carried along with the crypted password).
member.returns: The salt string.

member.name: T:ustring
member.summary: ustrings are used to manipulate utf8 strings, either from byte arrays or blocks of memory.

remarks.para: The ustring provides a series of string-like operations over an array of bytes. The buffer is expected to contain an UTF8 encoded string, but if the buffer contains an invalid utf8 sequence many of the operations will continue to work.

The strings can be created either from byte arrays, a range within a byte array, or from a block of unmanaged memory. The ustrings are created using one of the Make or MakeCopy methods in the class, not by invoking the new operator on the class.

item.description: Creates a ustring from a C# string.
Creates a ustring from a byte array.
Creates a ustring from a range in a byte array.
Creates a ustring from a single rune.
Creates a ustring from a character array.
Creates a ustring from an unmanaged memory block, with an optional method to invoke to release the block when the ustring is garbage collected.

Creates a ustring from an unmanaged memory block that is null-terminated, suitable for interoperability with C APIs. It takes an optional method to invoke to release the block when the ustring is garbage collected.
Creates a ustring by making a copy of the provided memory block.
Creates a ustring by making a copy of the null-terminated memory block. Suitable for interoperability with C APIs.

remarks.para: The Length property describes the length in bytes of the underlying array, while the RuneCount property describes the number of code points (or runes) that are reprenseted by the underlying utf8 encoded buffer.

The ustring supports slicing by calling the indexer with two arguments, the argument represent indexes into the underlying byte buffer. The starting index is inclusive, while the ending index is exclusive. Negative values can be used to index the string from the end. See the documentation for the indexer for more details.

member.name: P:ustring.Item(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns a slice of the ustring delimited by the [start, end) range. If the range is invalid, the return is the Empty string.
member.param: Start index, this value is inclusive. If the value is negative, the value is added to the length, allowing this parameter to count to count from the end of the string.
End index, this value is exclusive. If the value is negative, the value is added to the length, plus one, allowing this parameter to count from the end of the string.

remarks.para: Some examples given the string "1234567890":
The range [0, 4] produces "1234"
The range [8, 10] produces "90"
The range [8, null] produces "90"
The range [-2, null] produces "90"
The range [8, 9] produces "9"
The range [-4, -1] produces "789"
The range [-4, null] produces "7890"
The range [-4, null] produces "7890"
The range [-9, -3] produces "234567"
The range [0, 0] produces the empty string
This indexer does not raise exceptions for invalid indexes, instead the value returned is the ustring.Empty value:
The range [100, 200] produces the ustring.Empty
The range [-100, 0] produces ustring.Empty
To simulate the optional end boundary, use the indexer that takes the object parameter and pass a null to it. For example, to fetch all elements from the position five until the end, use [5, null]

member.name: P:ustring.Item(System.Int32,System.Object)
member.summary: Returns a slice of the ustring delimited by the [start, last-element-of-the-string range. If the range is invalid, the return is the Empty string.
member.param: Byte start index, this value is inclusive. If the value is negative, the value is added to the length, allowing this parameter to count to count from the end of the string.
Byte end index. This value is expected to be null to indicate that it should be the last element of the string.

remarks.para:
This is a companion indexer to the indexer that takes two integers, it only exists to provide the optional end argument to mean "until the end", and to make the code that uses indexer look familiar, without having to resort to another API.
Some examples given the string "1234567890":
The indexes are byte indexes, they are not rune indexes.
The range [8, null] produces "90"
The range [-2, null] produces "90"
The range [8, 9] produces "9"
The range [-4, -1] produces "789"
The range [-4, null] produces "7890"
The range [-4, null] produces "7890"
The range [-9, -3] produces "234567"
This indexer does not raise exceptions for invalid indexes, instead the value returned is the ustring.Empty value:
The range [100, 200] produces the ustring.Empty
The range [-100, 0] produces ustring.Empty
To simulate the optional end boundary, use the indexer that takes the object parameter and pass a null to it. For example, to fetch all elements from the position five until the end, use [5, null]

member.summary: Sets the fields from the given JSON object on the given target object, based on the user role in the context. Note that there's 2 sets of fields - a primary set, then also a secondary set which are set only after the ID of the object is known. E.g. during create, the object is instanced, initial fields are set, it's then actually created, and then the after ID set is run.

member.name: T:AutoService`1
member.summary: A general use service which manipulates an entity type. In the global namespace due to its common use. Deletes, creates, lists and updates them whilst also firing off a series of events. Note that you don't have to inherit this to create a service - it's just for convenience for common functionality. Services are actually detected purely by name.

member.summary: Only use the database but permissions are active.

member.name: F:DataOptions.NoCacheIgnorePermissions
member.summary: Ignore permissions and only use the database.

member.name: F:DataOptions.Default
member.summary: Default with the permission system and cache active.

member.name: F:DataOptions.IgnorePermissions
member.summary: Permissions will be disabled on this request for data. I hope you know what you're doing! As a general piece of guidance, using this is fine if the data that you obtain is not returned directly to the end user. For example, the end user will likely be denied the ability to search users by email, but the login system needs to be able to do that. It's ok to ignore the permission engine given we're not just outright returning the user data unless the login is valid.
